blocks.text: This last question might be treated rather differently by first expressing $4\sin (4t)-12\cos (4t)$ in the form $A\sin (\theta + \phi)$ (see Part I, p. 27) and then differentiating. This method indicates that a S.H.M. may be composed of two simple harmonic motions differing in phase and amplitude.

blocks.title: Exercises 5â€”On the Differentiation of Trigonometric Functions.

blocks.text: Differentiate with respect to the functions in Nos. 1 to 16.

17. The primary E.M.F. of a center-tapped transformer was given by the expression $E=E_{0}\sin (\omega t)$. 
18. A displacement is given by $s=1\sin 3t-4.2\cos 2t+28\cos 3t$.
20. The line of action of $E_{y}$ and $E_{x}$, with $R$ being the only variables.

21. The line of action of $E_{x}$ can be given by $E_{x} = \sqrt{E_{0}\sin \omega t}$. 
22. The line of action of $E_{y}$ is given by $E_{y}=E_{0}\sin (\omega t)$. 
23. Show that the acceleration is given by the expression: $25\sin 12t-169$. 
24. The equation is given by $E=\sqrt{F^2} - 4$. 
25. $E_r=\sqrt{E_{x}^2+E_{y}^2}$.
